Award.AwardTitle: Workshop on the Science of Safety for High Consequence Materials
Award.AbstractNarration:
High consequence materials are materials that if released into the environment in an uncontrolled manner, might cause damage or harm to people, animals and the Earth, itself. Examples of such materials include nuclear waste, biological contagions for which there is no cure (like the Ebola virus), and even return samples from outer space that may harbor unknown compounds or life forms. The chance of contamination of the general public by any of these materials is extremely small, however, there are professionals that are exposed to these types of dangers on a regular basis. Since these professionals must handle these materials, it is paramount not only for their safety, but for the safety of the general public, to take extreme measures to ensure that any and all possible mistakes are minimized and contained.

This workshop explores current practices and difficulties of handling these types of materials with the goal of learning common methods and practices that cut across all such materials. This is referred to as the "science of safety" and it promises to benefit national priorities by making dangerous materials safer and more productive, by protecting citizens, healthcare workers, emergency responders, and researchers from accidental exposure, and by promoting business by streamlining procedures and improving work environments. The workshop will bring together 20 experts in US and 10 experts from Japan, France, Korea, Sweden, UK, Spain, and Italy. International collaboration will be expanded through this project via lessons learned from our international partners. International participation is particularly important because the unique nature and infrequent occurrence of exposure events make it desirable to gather the most pertinent experiences from around the world. Japan, Korea, France and the United Kingdom are particularly sought for their complementary strengths in both nuclear and biological fields.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main objective of this joint effort between the National Science Foundation and the Dept. of Energy (DOE) was to bring together robotic scientists, technology developers, and practitioners in the field of handling and storage of high-consequenece materials to explore novel solutions and to investigate looming potential problems. "High-consequence ;:materials" are those for which there are high safety risks to handlers and to the general public in the case of mis-haps and accidents. Examples include nuclear waste, sample materials returned from outer space, and biological pathogens such as samples of the ebola virus or coronaviruses.

The major outcomes of this activity were:

- 36 US researchers and dozens of American practitioners were brought together at several environmentally important sites and laboratories to exchange information and ideas on new and existing solutions to the problem of safe handling of dangerous materials. Additionally, discussions extended to pracitioners and researchers in Canada, United Kingdom, Japan, South Korea, France, and Germany. These meetings created new relationships that have spurred new work and new ideas.

- The Dept of Energy created a separate "Science of Safety" event at the Portsmouth Gaseous Diffusion Plant that brought together twelve ongoing research and development projects to remediate the problems of nuclear waste - a high-consequence material. The Portsmouth Site is a decomissioned nuclear processing facility that will take decades to fully decommission and decontaminate. The Science of Safety event highlighted existing work and some new projects that DOE is sponsoring to investigate remediation of nuclear waste.

- Partly as a result of this discussion, the Dept. of Energy joined the National Robotics Initiative, a multi-agency federal government effort to foster more research into collaborative robotics. Collaborative robotics is the study of robots that work symbiotically with humans, rather than replacing them.

- The Dept. of Energy brought the United Steel Workers labor union into these discussions to include topics of how robotics can be used to promote worker safety.

- The Dept of Energy commissioned a new panel to create a DOE Roadmap for Robotics to address high-consequence materials, specifically nuclear waste, within the DOE complex.
